comments.body: if you already have a name, why not simply use the name?  Looks like you have both these set to the same value in the test.

Ah, good catch, this made me realize I simplified too much.
Attempted a proper name vs field manager dichotomy in #100061

If I understand it correctly, noteFn provides a way of notification. What bothers me is in what situation that the invoker might cares about it, maybe for metrics or logging? Take the priority-and-fairness server handler for example, in its entire request process, it doesn't need to know the existence of fs and plc. What's the purpose of expose noteFn?

We plan for a later PR to enhance the request handler to add the FlowSchema and PriorityLevelConfiguration UIDs to the response headers.  Exposing those early enables other uses as well, such as in logging or other metrics in the execFn (which is not always called, which is why the classification is exposed independently).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +51,55 @@	Handle(ctx context.Context,
		requestDigest RequestDigest,
		noteFn func(fs *fctypesv1a1.FlowSchema, pl *fctypesv1a1.PriorityLevelConfiguration),
		execFn func(),
	)

comments.body: I wouldn't bother to rename this import, let it be known as "clock".  We are trying to move everything that was using `k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/clock` to `k8s.io/utils/clock` so that we can retire `k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/clock`.
we have two clock packages being used here - `fairqueuing` and `utils`, so the prefix makes it more explicit, but i am fine either way.

`k8s.io/utils/clock` is the base clock package.  `k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/util/flowcontrol/fairqueuing/clock` builds on that, adding `EventClock`.  Now that I think of it, it would be better if the latter were `k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/util/flowcontrol/fairqueuing/eventclock`.
@MikeSpreitzer  yes, i agree, `eventclock` is a better name - can we merge this PR? I am happy to open a separate PR with the rename.
